title: Do we need to adhere to the Open-Closed Principle if we have good test coverage?
内容: The open-closed principle is about preventing sweeping changes. Even if you have every part of your application covered with tests, that doesn't mean that you can easily add or change your code base. A recent client of mine had a code base that had a very high percentage of code coverage, but making changes was still really painful. One of the reasons was that even small feature requests lead to large ripples through the system (an OCP violation). This was in many cases so costly, that management sometimes decided to cancel such feature request.

title: Is DI possible without a managed heap?

title: Dependency Injection with Repository Pattern or only DI?

In other words, if you can resolve IEnumerable<IHandler<SubType>> and that list might also contain IHandler<BaseType>, but not the other way around.

title: Accessing Headers in .NET Core and Autofac
内容: The IMyService seems to be overly generic. There should never be some business logic that is interested in all request headers. So instead, I would advise defining role-based interfaces, where the interface is specified for the application's particular needs. For instance, I imagine an ITenantContext interface with a string CurrentTenant { get; } property. The underlying AspNetTenantContext implementation will load the value from the request headers. Likewise there could be other interfaces as well, such as IUserContext etc., that are focussed on one particular question.

title: Register all implemented interfaces by a type with Simple Injector
内容: I can't fully grasp what you are trying to accomplish. I can't see why you want (or why that even could work) to use Register in case there's just one element in the collection and RegisterCollection when you have 0 or multiple. An abstraction is typically -either- a one-to-one mapping -or- part of a collection. It is very unlikely you wish to register such type as one-to-one (i.e. Register) simply because there is just one registration, even though you have determined it is part of a collection. That's why Simple Injector makes the distinction between one-to-one and one-to-many explicit

title: Simple Injector fallback to Xamarin Forms DependencyService

At this point you have a reference to all assemblies and should be able to register all components. Falling back seems like failing silently to me. You don't want to do this.

title: Does Simple Injector have a way to RegisterConditional with object factory?

title: Entity Framework - Make the generated signatures of procedures and function not dependent on EF
内容: I encountered such system a few years back. What I advised the team was to wrap these stored procedures in command/handler pairs and query/handler pairs, while keeping those SPs in tact initially. This allowed them to cut away a massive amount of cross-cutting code that was tangled with business code. This made the system much more adaptable and maintainable, because it become childs play to add cross-cutting concerns like caching, validation, or security checks.

内容: @mcanti: The original question is about running this code during application startup. The start-up part of the application already has (and will always have) a dependency on your DI container. Creating an execution context scope when a scoped instance is requested is not advised, since it becomes unclear when to end/dispose that scope.

title: Using Simple Injector to register ISolrAbstractResponseParser<>
内容: Tha'ts because you didn't switch to Register(Type, Type) as the error explained, but to Register(Type, IEnumerable<Assembly>). The former maps an open generic abstraction to an open generic implementation, while the latter batch-registers all non-generic implementations found in the supplied assemblies that implement a closed generic version of the supplied abstraction (which will probably be none in your case).

title: Structuremap singleton usage
内容: Only you know whether or not it is safe to have only one instance of CacheHelper<T> and ApprovedProgrammesHelper or not. If it (or its dependencies) have any (mutable) state and aren't thread-safe it is probably unwise to define them as singleton. There is no way anyone can answer this question for you without seeing the code for both classes, their dependencies and knowing in which context (such as framework) this code runs.

title: IOC container assembly scanning performance
内容: Most containers allow you to replace a made registration after it was made. This allows you to do common batch-registration and swap out a few specific implementations. My personal preference is to only use batch-registration on generic types like IQueryHandler<T, R> and ICommandHandler<T>. These generic abstractions span 80% to 95% of the components in my system, which leaves just a few components that require hand-wiring. This gives me full flexibility, because the hand-wired types are usually the ones that might need swapping out (for different configuration settings or strategies e.g.)

title: Dependency Injection ASP.NET : Unaware about the dependencies until Runtime

This will probably work well in your crypto use case where the real implementations will probably have no dependencies on their own and are thread-safe. More than often, these conditions don't hold and it would be better to make the container in control of the object graph. This allows the graph to be verified and diagnosed and makes it easier to replace, decorate or intercept components.

title: How to configure DI services available to the Startup class constructor
内容: @ZoolWay: My advise it to not use auto-wiring in the WebHostBuilder (i.e. refrain from using one of the AddXXX<TService, TImplementation>() method calls). The only safe method to use is the AddSingleton<T>(T) overload. In other words, create your class by hand, e.g.: services.AddSingleton<IMyService>(new MyService());. This will prevent any future problems such as Torn lifestyles, captive dependencies and other hard to track problems.

title: How to configure DI services available to the Startup class constructor
内容: You are right about ASP.NET having 2 internal containers, but are wrong about having to reconfigure them again. The registered IMyService will be available in the application container as well. Problem however is that by building 2 container instances, ASP.NET introduces the problem of a Torn Lifestyle, because when that IMyService is resolved again later on, a new instance is created (since there will be a singleton per container). Reconfiguring that instance in the container will not solve the issue, because you'll still end up with two instances.

title: Autofac dispose order

title: DbContext object has been disposed: how can I prevent the object to be disposed?
内容: You should not implement IDisposable on GenericUoW. Do not inject dispose injected depenencies, because the consuming class does not have the ownership of the dependencies (only the Composition Root and the container do) and it does not know whether or not the dependency (the DbContext in this case) should be disposed or not. Removing the Dispose functionality might actually solve your problem, although it is hard to tell, because enough details are missing to describe the exact cause.

title: Autofac: Resolving generic interface in a generic method
内容: What's important to add here is that you should only injecy ILifetimeScope instances in classes that are part of your composition root (to prevent the rest of the application from taking a dependency on the container). This means that the ClientClass should implement an abstraction. This IClientClass abstraction can be placed central to the application and referable to other code, while the ClientClass implementation can be placed inside the Composition Root.

title: RegisterType (typeof) vs RegisterType
内容: The advantage of the generic overload is the fact that the C# compiler will do the type checking for you (at compile time) instead of letting the code fail at runtime when TFrom is not assignable from TTo.

title: Dependency Injection Abstraction Library
内容: @Raine: You should not do the same as ASP.NET Core does with their DI abstraction. They made a huge mistake in creating their abstraction, since almost none of the DI library maintainers is able to create a compatible adapter on top of that abstraction (including Autofac and Simple Injector). For the next release of ASP.NET Core (v1.1) Microsoft has promised to improve integration scenarios in the same way as Mark Seemann proposed in the blog posts I referred to. So copying their DI abstraction is a really bad idea.

Everything is wired inside the Composition Root, but nothing depends on the Composition Root.

title: C# Castle Windsor injected properties are always null
内容: Property injection is bad, because it causes Temporal Coupling and either causes your code to have a dependency on the DI library (because you'll mark your code with attributes) or you'll tell the DI library to inject a dependency when it can, which means your application will fail silently when a required dependency is missing. This all can be solved by sticking with constructor injection.

title: Does overriding violate the Open/Closed principle?

Low cohesion is often an indication of a Single Responsibility Violation violation. You'll often see base classes being abused to implement cross-cutting concerns. Having multiple cross-cutting concerns in one base class is a SRP violation.

title: Does overriding violate the Open/Closed principle?
内容: @anotherdave Having concrete methods on a base class is not a violation of the ISP, but having concrete methods on a base class that aren't used by a derivate actually is an ISP violation. Whether the client uses them or not is irrelevant, since the ISP states "no client should be forced to depend on methods it does not use". The same holds for wide interfaces, where the client just uses 1 out of 10 methods. It still depends on the other 9 methods, that are "already there".

title: C# Castle Windsor injected properties are always null

title: Dependency injection in ASP.NET WebAPI: IHttpControllerActivator vs. IDependencyResolver
内容: The problem with the IDependencyResolver interface is that it is too generic and forces a consumer to return null if a service can't be resolved (instead of throwing an exception). This is why there are hundreds of questions here on SO about the "controllers should have a default constructor" exception message. Implementing the IHttpControllerActivator solves this problem, because its contract does not allow returning null.

title: Serilog's ILogger injected using Log.ForContext<T>, where T is the consumer
内容: We explicitly left out the possibility to register a delegate with the RegisterConditional method, because that would allow making runtime decisions during object graph creation, and it disallows Simple Injector from doing deep analysis on your object graphs. So that trick here is to wrap the Log.ForContext<T> call inside a self-defined generic class, which is exactly what @janhartmann advices. Whether or not you hide Serilog behind your own abstraction is up to you, but I do absolutely advice doing this. So for me, Jan's answer is the correct answer.

title: Another way to instantiate the base part of a derived class with injecting the base in the ctor?
内容: Base classes with dependencies tend to be used to apply cross-cutting concerns (CCC). When this happens SRP is violated, because the base class has many responsibilities (one for each CCC). OCP is violated because you will have to change the base class (and the ctor of all implementations) every time a new CCC is added. The base class will often expose many methods to the inheritors, while each inheritor will just use a few; this is a ISP violation.

title: How to resolve runtime dependencies in castle windsor for C#
内容: First of all, since you will have possibly many repositories that require a connection, hide the connection string behind an IConnectionFactory or IDbContextProvider abstraction (depending on your needs of course). With such abstraction it becomes trivial to create an adapter implementation that gets the proper connection string at runtime and either creates a new SqlConnection or DbContext. The repository than calls connectionFactory.CreateConnection() or dbContextProvider.CurrentContext.

title: Is running a query from a command a violation of Command-Query Separation?
内容: My preference is to view ICommandHandler as holistic abstraction, but IQueryHandler not. It of course depends on the application you are writing, but I find it really common to compose queries out of smaller queries and having one abstraction for them has given me the best overall experience. With commands on the other hand, my 'strategy' is to place all logic inside the handler until it becomes unmanageable. In that case I either extract Aggregate Services or move logic into event handlers. My command handlers simply execute queries.

title: DI MVC 6 - register Generics

I would suggest switching to Simple Injector, Autofac or StructureMap.

title: Simple Injector terminology clarify
内容: @Merryweather: If an instance is registered per WebRequestLifestyle, there will be only one instance per web request per container. If your register an instance as Singleton, there will only one instance per container. So if you create multiple Container instances, there will be multiple instances. You will however, usually create just a single container instance for the duration of the lifetime of your application.

title: SimpleInjector ActivatorException when resolving COM interop type
内容: You're directly injecting COM objects into your application services? Yuck! That might be a Dependency Inversion Principle violation. The DIP states that your classes should talk to application specific abstractions. This probably means that you create an adapter that wraps the COM object. This prevents you from having to inject the COM object. COM objects such, because you are talking to proxies. Such proxy object can cause SI to see two different types; this might be troubling you.

title: Simple Injector get current principal in WebAPI using OWIN

title: One DbContext per web request… why?
内容: This is an interesting answer and I partially agree with you. To me, a DbContext doesn't have to be tied to a web request, but it IS always typed to one single 'request' as in: 'business transaction'. And when you tie the context to a business transaction, change cancellation becomes really weird to do. But not having it on web request boundary doesn't mean that the business components (BCs) should be creating the context; I think that is not their responsibility. Instead, you can apply scoping using decorators around your BCs. This way you can even change scoping without any code change.

title: Simple Injector get current principal in WebAPI using OWIN
内容: I simplified your registration a bit by making the factory a singleton; since there's no need in creating a new delegate on each request. Note that you should never call the factory inside an injection constructor, as I explained in the comment on Erik's answer. In your case it even yields invalid results, because the principal might not be available during object graph construction. In other words, while a factory is meant to delay object construction, you don't delay anything, because the delegate is called inside the ctor.

title: What is the Equivalent of PropertiesAutoWired of Autofac in Ninject
内容: Do note that PropertiesAutoWired behaves very different compared to [Inject] attribute. Autofac's PropertiesAutoWired implements implicit property injection (which means it skips a property if it can't be injected), while Ninject's [Inject] attribute implements explicit property injection (which means the container will fail-fast when a dependency can't be injected. Although explicit property injection is much safer, with Ninject this means marking your code base with (framework-specific) attributes, which isn't very attractive either.

title: IoC/DI: How to inject specific instance when there are multiple implementations of same interface
内容: Note that the Consumer property of the PredicateContext describes the 'consuming class of the current dependency' (or parent), while the Consumer.Target describes the constructor parameter or property that the dependency is injected into. So Consumer.Target.TargetType will (almost) always be equal to the type of registration (in your case IService). Consumer.Target is more useful for getting the property or parameter name or can be used to query for certain attributes.

title: Implementing asynchronous scoping in PCL and Windows Phone applications
内容: I agree it's bad for business logic, but transparent contexts (like the TransactionScope) are great for infrastructural concerns and they actually make the life of developers much easier. Simple Injector (a DI lib) has based its design of scoped lifestyles around this concept and this makes the developer's life much easier, because it allows their business logic to be completely oblivious of the scope it is running in. Passing through the DI container's scope throughout the system leads to strong coupling on the DI container, which is bad practice.

title: Is ServiceLocator an anti-pattern?
内容: When you're dealing with legacy code, everything is justified to get you out of that mess, even if it means taking intermediate (and imperfect) steps. The Service Locator is such intermediate step. It allows you get out of that hell one step at the time, as long as you remember that a good alternative solution exists that is documented, repeatable and proven to be effective. This alternative solution is Dependency Injection and this is precisely why the Service Locator is still an anti-pattern; properly designed software doesn't use this it.

title: DBContext Not Being Disposed on Simple Injector
内容: Simple Injector will guarantee to dispose WebRequestLifestyle registrations automatically when the web request ends. In other words, you can be quite certain that EFAppContext is disposed, so the problem is probably somewhere else. But if in doubt, do override Dispose in your EFAppContext and set a breakpoint in both the constructor and the dispose method to verify whether each instance is disposed.

内容: @Slowacki: Simple Injector is very strict in his conditional registrations. For instance, if it finds two applicable conditional registrations when resolving a service, it will throw an exception. Simple Injector hardly ever fails silently. But as you already noticed, Simple Injector does not allow overriding conditional registrations, because that would lead to ambiguity (and thus meant Simple Injector would failing silently, which is something we tend to prevent).

title: Can I use DI container down in the hierarchy?
内容: @Narek: No, after the application started, the object graphs should be fixed and should never change in shape or structure. Changing how object graphs are constructed at runtime makes it really hard to verify the correctness of the graph, and making changes to your container at runtime will cause all sorts of grief. If you still think this is required, please post a new question here on SO, and I will prove to you this isn't needed.

title: Continued Ninject support in ASP.NET MVC 6?
内容: @Spets The built-in container is especially meant as a configuration system for ASP.NET itself. So this means that you can easily swap parts of ASP.NET and 3rd party components can use the same configuration model. The built-in container is built around that model, and that explains why some features are not inplemented. Note that batch-registration is really easy to write yourself on top of the container, and to become a compelling DI library other more important features should be implemented first. But again, don't abuse the DI system for registering your own types.

title: Replace activator for middleware in ASP.NET Core
内容: @opiants: You shouldn't see it as "2 DI containers". You just have one DI container for your application, and you have the "configuration system of ASP.NET" which internally happens to look like a DI container. In a sense things aren't any different as before. MVC and Web API already had their own configuration system; we never wanted to replace their complete internal configuration system. That doesn't really make sense.

You can as easily make the registration as follows: container.RegisterSingleton<ICommandService>(new CommandService(container.GetInstance)). I agree, don't make the following registration: container.RegisterSingleton<Func<Type, object>>(container.GetInstance). That will easily lead to the Service Locator anti-pattern.

title: Replace activator for middleware in ASP.NET Core
内容: @opiants: That shouldn't be a problem, since you should typically not inject those framework types into your own components. You need to write application-specific abstraction and write an implementation that adapts to those framework pieces to keep your application clean anyway (that's what the DIP advices). Such specific implementation can get the specific framework type injected. And even if you make it less clean, you typically need a handful of types that you need to share. You can register a simple delegate that calls the 'other' container to request the required type.

For your application components, use the IOC container that suits you best.

title: How to make dependency injection only when explicitly request it?
内容: So you want to place the registrations in the assembly where the types originate from? You can create a public static Bootstrapper class in that assembly with a RegisterTypes(IUnityContainer container) method and call that method from within your Global.asax. This prevents you from having to update the Global.asax for every change in that assembly. Do note that the start-up project references all other projects, so this project will have to be recompiled and redeployed anyway. So this 'not having to update the global.asax', might not be a real advantage.

title: Dependency Injection - passing parameters to constructed types
内容: The source of your problems is that you inject runtime data (the Contract instance) into the constructor of you components (the ContractWindowViewModel in this case). Your object graphs should be stateless, and runtime data should be passed through an existing object graph using method calls. Any time you violate that idea, you make everything much harder (as you are already experiencing). So instead of injecting the Contract using the constructor, define a method on your view model that allows setting the existing contract.

title: Simple injector - decorators causing container to not be garbage collected?

title: Interface segregation and single responsibility principle woes
内容: So every class in your system that consumes this IRepository<T> interface uses all of its methods (all six in your example)? I've actually never seen this happen in any system, and I bet that this doesn't happen in your systems. Some classes will only use Delete, while others will only call Read. As you said, "Delete() might not be required at all". This is in essence an ISP violation, since it states that "no client should be forced to depend on methods it does not use.". It might not always be a problem to violate ISP, but it is important to understand.

title: Creating a small IoC Container in C#

title: Dependency injection example
内容: @YacoubMassad: The applications I write (which are usually quite large) conform to SOLID and contain hundreds small (focused) classes, mostly placed behind a a few generic abstractions and often have one or multiple generic decorators (sometimes with generic type constraints) applied to them. In that case it becomes quite cumbersome to hand-wire all those classes with all those dependencies. That's when batch-registration and auto-wiring becomes really valuable. I've described this type of design here for instance.

What I did was wrap the mapper type in a decorator-like type that is both implicitly implemented and a public type (dynamic will fail on an internal type, even though the interface is public). You could even let Autofac resolve the MapperWrapper<,> for you.

title: Creating a small IoC Container in C#

title: Dependency injection example
内容: @duffymo: DI is not about tooling, it's about patterns. I agree with much that Yacoub says. Pure DI has many advantages and good design and good practices, could make DI libraries superfluous (and do note that I maintain a [DI library](simpleinjector.org] myself). I usually advice developers to start of with Pure DI, and switch to a DI library when maintaining the Composition Root becomes cumbersome. In the applications I write and maintain however, it wouldn't be very practical to live without a DI library.

title: Castle Windsor multiple implementations of interface
内容: It doesn't really matter that the interfaces look the same; what's important is their contract and their behavior is different. They behave differently and are therefore contractually different. This means that they need both a different interface; The SOLID principles don't lie.

title: Dependency injection example

I think it is good to stay away from crazy and fragile features of the DI container, and hand-wire components that have more complex needs, your article seems to imply that for that reason it is better to go with Pure DI completely. These options however aren't mutually exclusive; you can register delegates that contain hand-wired components, mixed with the bulk of your configuration being auto-wired (and preferably registered using batch-registration).

title: Ninject dynamically bind to implementation
内容: @BatteryBackupUnit: For me it's all about hiding implementation details for the consumer. Having a Func<Asm, IExport> or ExportDictionary injected into consumers makes them aware of the existence of multiple implementations and a consumer gets an extra concept/abstraction to work with. But in the end, it depends on context, because with my solution the OP might be required to change the IExport interface. Although the changed abstraction might be better, but if changing is not an possible, you'll again end up with an extra factory/provider like abstraction like your IExportDictionary.

title: Implementation and usage of logger wrapper for log4net
内容: @TimLaax: Making that logger a singleton / ambient context, doesn't change the fact that it is a dependency; but it does make the dependency hidden. This makes it hard to test, mock, replace,decorate and intercept, hides the fact for any consumer that this dependency exist, and makes it impossible for the a tool (such as your DI library) to analyze the object graph for you. In my book, making the logger a singleton is absolutely not better nor cleaner. Making it a singleton is treatment of symptoms. You are injecting the logger in way too many classes: stop doing that.

title: Simple Injector Register All Services From Namespace
内容: @Neshta: Simple Injector however focuses on applications that are designed around the SOLID and RAP principles. These types of applications don't have many one-to-one mappings between interfaces and implementations and this will (besides other things) minimize the problem. Instead of trying to design an API that works great for all types of applications (which is actually really difficult) we choose to focus on one type, in the hope we push developers towards SOLID design.

title: Dependency Injection Unity - Conditional resolving
内容: Your friend might be right. Take a close look if you aren't violating the Liskov Substitution Principle. If the implementations of IAuthenticate are not interchangeable for one another (which means that a consumer such as the AuthenticateController will not work correctly if it gets the wrong implementation), you are violating LSP. The solution in that case is often to give each implementation its own abstraction.

title: Unity change RegisterType for controller (two contexts)
内容: The root cause here is that you violate the Liskov Substitution Principle. You are using two different contexts with different data models. Swapping the implementations will break your application (which means you're violating LSP). You should give each context each own interface and this solves the problem completely. It's irrelevant that those two interfaces seem to have the same method signatures; their contract is very different.

title: How to disable resolving of un-registered types in simpleInjector?
内容: You can call the container's GetService method (by casting to IServiceProvider). This will return null for unregistered/unresolvable types.

title: ASP.NET Web Api Dependency Injection - Singleton or not
内容: But a DbContext should not be injected as dependency into a constructor. The object graphs you resolve should purely consist of components (classes that contain the application's behavior) and they should typically be stateless. A DbContext is neither: it contains no application behavior and is merely a big request-specific state bag. Instead of injecting the DbContext, you should pass it through the object graph like you do with all other state. There are multiple ways to do this, such as using an IDbContextProvider abstraction with a CurrentContext property or use IUnitOfWork.

title: Do I need to worry about an object being thread safe if it has no static fields?
内容: Making objects immutable is a lot of work in C#. IMO its not worth the trouble. It's much easier to give each request it's own freshly deserialized objects. Or define all your query and response types in F# and consume them in C#. Best of both worlds.

title: Autofac and Contract classes
内容: This is very fragile and I would advise against trying to filter out types that are marked with either [ContractClass] or [ContractClassFor] because those attributes themselves are marked with the [Conditional("CONTRACTS_FULL")] attribute, which means that when the assembly is built without the conditional compilation symbol CONTRACTS_FULL, the type will become a 'normal' type and will again be registered. Developers are likely to remove this symbol in RELEASE configuration. So the problem is that this bug will only show up in UAT or production where you actually use a release build.

But once you start adding cross-cutting concerns such as logging, audit trailing, permission checks, validation, transaction management, etc, etc, you'll be happy if you have an architecture that allows you to add cross-cutting concerns in a simple and elegant way using [decorators ](en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decorator_pattern). It's simply impossible to apply decorators with the vNext container as you can do with one of the mature containers.

In that case all your components will be stateless and depend solely on singletons. In that case there are only advantages. But if you have components with state on the other hand, making them singleton can cause race conditions and other multi-threading related bugs.

title: Attribute based interception with Castle.DynamicProxy and Simple Injector
内容: @sp7:  There is nothing 'to solve' in Simple Injector, because Simple Injector doesn't support interception at all. This is a very deliberate design decision,  because we feel that interception is an indication of poorly designed software, where Simple Injector tries to push developers into good practice. Unless we change our philosophy, interception support will never be supported. So don't expect this and if you can, improve your application design instead of depending on interception.

title: Importing objects in a default constructor using MEF

Third, your components should always only have 1 single constructor.

title: Ninject Singleton not being injected as Singleton into Dependent Class
内容: You are making two bindings, which basically means two registrations in the internal dictionary. The first has a key of PersonalityConfiguration and the second has IPersonalityProvider. Ninject will simply lookup a resolution based on the key in this dictionary and those two registrations are not related in any way. What Ninject is concerned they are completely different, even though they share the same implementation type.

title: Property injection with Simple Injector 1 in Unity3D under .NET 3.5
内容: @MickyDuncan: DI is about writing loosely coupled code. But DI is about patterns; not about tools. So it is always good to question whether a DI library is an improvement. Using factories instead of DI however doesn't result in the same amount of loose coupling. DI typically gives the most flexibility, while keeping our code simple and maintainable. Using DI might indeed be overkill if used "for a few singletons", but that is different from having a big object graph that consist solely of singletons. I use DI to determine how the object graph is composed when the application starts.

title: Ninject generic type xml binding
内容: Why do you need to use this using XML? Configuration of DI structure using XML is fragile, verbose and error prone. Consider using code-first registrations instead, and for everything that actually needs to change after deployment, only put configuration switches in your configuration file, instead of using the fully qualified names.

title: Property injection with Simple Injector 1 in Unity3D under .NET 3.5
内容: @MickyDuncan: I didn't mean that perf of a game is irrelevant. But when building up an object graph with singletons, you will only have to build up this graph once and that will cause the resolve-time to become irrelevant, even if very heavy reflection is used. You are absolutely right that DI libraries use reflection. The use of external tools increase the memory footprint, and so do any jitted .NET code. But do note however that Simple Injector optimizes resolving objects by compiling and caching delegates. This means that there is a one-time cost with reflection.

title: How do I use GetAll with Ninject so that one failure doesn't stop the other bindings from resolving?

Of course you are free to ask this, but I think that if you change your design, you don't have to ask this question at all. If some registration exists, it must be possible to resolve it. Failing to do so is a bug in the application. If a plugin didn't supply such command, it should simply not be in the list and this allows you to resolve the complete list without risk of failure.

title: Using contextual information for resolution predicate
内容: @AlexFoxGill: Technically this would be possible, but this is not something I would promote. I'm actually currently working on v3 and we're improving support for conditional registrations in that release. But after a thorough discussion we concluded that the supplied predicate should not allow access to runtime information. Although your example would work in case Ancestors is reevaluated on each call, there is still a risk of users calling it directly during build-time. The general idea of supplying a factory promotes runtime decisions to be made during construction, which is not wise.

内容: Calling SaveChanges at that point in the request is a bad idea. Please read this q/a. To quote the answer: "... at the end of the request. Many people however, incorrectly assume that this is also the place to Commit the unit of work. However, at that point in the application, you simply can't determine for sure that the unit of work should actually be committed. e.g. If the business layer code threw an exception that was caught higher up the callstack, you definitely don't want to Commit.".

That IUserContext abstraction should never do anything else than getting the current user. If you need data from the query string etc, you are probably getting different information and this deserves an abstraction on its own. The hard part of course is getting your abstractions right, but it usually gets much easier if you start by sticking to the basic principles (the SOLID principles).

title: Static class to dependency injection

title: Does Unity have 'registration modules'?
内容: A modules/installers/registries feature is usually very useless, because in most cases you can achieve the same by extracting the relevant code to a public static class and call that class from within your main application. Modules are especially useful in cases you want to load assemblies dynamically without having a compile-time dependency, which is only useful in plugin scenarios.

title: What is the equivalent of HybridHttpOrThreadLocalScoped in structure map 3?

But even if you use per-thread lifestyle in your unit tests, this is still not a good reason to use this HybridHttpOrThreadLocalScoped in your production configuration, because in case of the absence of a HTTP context, an object will live for the duration of the application; hardly ever a good idea.

title: Assign implementation based on assembly
内容: If AlphaRepository<T> breaks when a BetaContext context is injected, you are violating the Liskov Substitution Principle and this is the root of your trouble. Instead, give each context its own abstraction and let each repository depend on that abstraction, or depend on the concrete type directly. This solves the LSP violation, and solves your registration troubles completely.

title: Resolve the dependency of Command Handler with castle windsor

title: Registering Generic decorators in castle windsor?
内容: @Xerxes: My current preference is to prevent injecting any state related elements into the object graph completely. Instead, try to build an object graph that is built-up by singletons completely. e.g. instead of injecting an DbContext into a handler, inject an IContextProvider that contains a Context property that retrieves the DbContext for the current request. Or -even better- have an IUnitOfWork abstraction with a single IQueryable<T> Set<T>() method. The IUnitOfWork can be a singleton and the Set<T> method retrieves the underlighing DbContext for the current request.

title: How to prevent constructor misuse in c# class
内容: @JitendraPancholi: Yes. As the answer describes, it's about layering. Your main application assembly (in MVC) contains two layers: the composition root layer and the UI layer and there is nothing wrong with this, because layers are about logical structuring, not physical structuring. The composition root layer depends on the DAL classes, while the UI layer should only depend on the DAL interfaces. The DAL interfaces can be in the same assembly as the classes, but still in a different layer.

title: Why Unit Of Work and InRequestScope Ninject creates 2 instances of dbcontext?
内容: Are you running .NET 4.0 or .NET 4.5? Are you using the UseTaskFriendlySynchronizationContext or the LegacyAspNetSynchronizationContext (see here)? Under certain configurations, the HttpContext.Current can become when async methods return, and unfortunately Ninject will in that case just resolve a transient instance instance, instead of throwing an exception (a design flow IMO).

title: DI with command pattern

title: Polymorphism and Dependency injection
内容: @red2nb: I would advice not doing constructor and property injection into entities and solely use method injection. Entities are short-lived objects and your container should not build them. So don't do Resolve<Entity> but injecting dependencies into an entity's method (as you do with AbtractMethod is fine though).

title: Specifying a separate injection for a particular interface
内容: @JoeMighty: The LSP says that you should be able to swap implementations of the same abstraction without the consumer to know the difference. The OP uses the same IDatabase abstraction over multiple database schemas and the consumers of this IDatabase schema depend on the actual schema. Thus, in that case swapping those implementations will cause the system to break, because the consumer (say ManageUsersController will call this.database.Get<Users>() to return a list of users, but if it is injected with the implementation for the "users databsae", the system will fail. This breaks LSP.

title: Autofac (+MVC + EF + SignalR + Hangfire) lifetime scopes
内容: I can't answer the question about "how do you manage disposal of component created by factory" in the context of Autofac. With Simple Injector it is dead simple. You don't have to do anything. Simple Injector will resolve it for you from an active scope (and will throw an exception if there is no scope) and Simple Injector will dispose your instance when the scope ends. Scopes are ambient (just like TransactionScope) and don't have to be passed around. This makes life much easier.

内容: I'm sorry. My assumption was that would work, because Func<DbContext> is a singleton, just as ChatService. My assumption was that the Func<DbContext> would produce a new instance based on the lifestyle, but after some experimenting, I have to conclude that the Func<T> behaves differently when injected into a singleton. A Func<T> in Autofac produces a singleton when injected into a singleton, even when the DoSomething is called in the context of a lifetime scope. This is REALLY confusing IMO. But this explains why you have to take a dependency on Owned<T> in Autofac's case.

Do note though that in general your application code should not have to deal with threading and parallelism and you should prevent moving dependencies from thread to thread from within your application. This is infrastructural logic that should be separated from application code and placed inside the Composition Root of the application.

title: MVC5 Ninject binding and HttpContext
内容: Liskov Substitution Principle is not about being able to mock a HttpContext. As a matter of fact, base classes can never violate the LSP; their sub types however will violate the LSP when they don't conform to the base class'es contract. So the real problem with the HttpContext is that the CONSUMER of the HttpContext will violate both the Dependency Inversion Principle AND Interface Segregation Principle, since HttpContext is not an abstraction and the consumer is forced to depend on methods it does not use.

If you access the container from WITHIN your Composition Root, this is NOT an implementation of the Service Locator anti-pattern. Do read this. Long story short, as long as you define your Translator Factory implementation INSIDE your Composition Root, you are fine and are not applying the service locator pattern.

title: Autofac (+MVC + EF + SignalR + Hangfire) lifetime scopes
内容: Perhaps I misunderstand how Autofac works, but the use of Owned<T> seems superfluous. If the DbContext is registered as InstancePerLifetimeScope, Autofac should automatically dispose that DbContextinstance when its surrounding lifetime scope ends. In other words, it should be enough to inject an Func<DbContext>. Problem however with Autofac is that in case there is no active lifetime scope, the DbContext is resolved as singleton (a design flaw IMO). That makes it a little tricky.

title: How to inject ModelState as parameter with Ninject?

So +1 for your last sentence.

title: Reflection: “Could not load file or assembly” Double dependency inversion

However, dynamically loading assemblies to prevent letting the startup project taking a reference on other projects is almost never needed. So you are taking the concept of loosely coupled code a step too far. Do note that even though your assemblies reference each other, the classes are still loosely coupled.

Just different layers of abstractions.

title: Dependency injection with multiple-layered application
内容: @Matthias: This isn't about DI containers. Each class should simply accept the dependencies it (directly) needs as constructor arguments and in the startup path of the application you build up the complete object graph(s) (the Composition Root). You don't need a DI container to do this and it can even have benefits to not use a container at all. On the other hand, a DI container can help making your Composition Root much more maintainable.

Still, in the case of registration of generic decorators, this will only work if either the decorator contains generic type constraints, or the decorator is registered with a filter predicate. Otherwise, Simple Injector will almost certainly throw a “cyclic dependency detected” exception.

title: Change current implementation of basic MVVM to adhere to SOLID pattern
内容: @BalrajSingh: The ICommand of WPF is an implementation of the Gang of Four Command Pattern. That pattern is tailored for UIs, were undo/redo might be important. The pattern described here does not have an official name, but I usually refer to it as the 'command/handler pattern'. It is especially suited for business logic. Difference with the command pattern is that the command/handler separates data (the command or message) from behavior (the handler), while the GOF command pattern places data and behavior in one class (the command).

title: Register Components Based on appsetting value?

If you have to restart the application anyway (because it is a configuration switch as is the case with the OP), the preferred solution should IMO be to leave Castle's configuration as simple as possible. Castle's diagnostic services will b e unaware of the existence of such switch and will make it blind. Same holds for any integration test you write to automatically test the container's configuration for correctness.

title: Using Simple Injector in Web API and OWIN
内容: That's incorrect. Although Verify will go through all registrations and check whether they can be created, you need to redirect the default Web API controller creation mechanism to Simple Injector. That's what the SimpleInjectorWebApiDependencyResolver is for. Web API will use this resolver to create a controller on each request. But if something else changes this resolver (or decides to use a different one), Simple Injector will not be asked to create a controller and you'll fall back to the default behavior of Web API.

Typically you want to check that 'certain types of classes' are not references as singletons, but are injected into the constructor using their interfaces. The question really is here how to define those 'certain types of classes' and how to detect that they are references and newed up directly instead of injected through their interface. I'm not sure that the template patterns are flexible enough to do this kind of deep analysis.

title: How to do a registration in Simple Injector after a GetInstance call / Alternate solution?

However, with Simple Injector you can register an anonymous factory (using Func<T>) without any problem, there's no limitation preventing you from doing that. I do however see the use of a factory as a useless extra layer of indirection in this case.

title: SimpleInjector and Caliburn Micro , Viewmodel auto-wired other class no

title: Is this List<T> property thread-safe?
内容: @EpiX: Strictly spoken not. Advantage of having a lock is that it adds a memory barrier. This clears the cache and prevents other threads from getting an old (already cached) reference. So it prevents other threads from getting the old value even after set is called. But since lock is already used in the get, the lock in set is redundant. However, I do like to use lock in both set and get, because this is in most cases required and makes the code less confusing this that case. If we would remove the lock from set, we will have to comment explicitly why that lock is not required

title: Better way to resolve the binding of multiple services when the context is the same in Ninject?
内容: Your ClassToDeserialize seems to be a DTO. DTOs, entities, messages, and other classes that hold data should not be registered in your container. Containers are for resolving components; classes that have behavior. Any time you try to mix data and behavior and register it in your container, things will go wrong. So data classes should not have dependencies. They should simply be 'pushed' through the object graph that you resolved using your container. You should refactor your code accordingly and a lot of problems will disapear when doing that.

title: Why is coupling to dependencies with the new keyword considered bad?
内容: Take a look at this great talk by Robert C. Martin about OO design. It talks about the Dependency Inversion Principle, which is the main driver behind Dependency Injection. Martin talks about the "Copy Program" (an example he used throughout the years) in which he explains what the problem of source code dependencies and class coupling is. We use DI to lower class coupling. Watch this talk, because this should be your main argument to your colleagues.

title: autofac and multithreading
内容: @koo9: nope, no service locator needs to be harmed when doing this. Put an abstraction around the code that processes stuff in parallel, and create an implementation of this in your composition root. This implementation can call back into the container, and since this is located inside your composition root, this is no form of service locator.

title: Simple Injector conditional injection
内容: This question has come up multiple times on Stackoverflow, and it is my duty to question such design. Although such design is not always wrong, you have to be careful not to violate the Liskov Substitution Principle. So the question is, does ControllerA still works when it is injected with FooB, or does is breaks? If it breaks, you are violating LSP and this means that FooA and FooB should each implement a different interface.

内容: The trick is that you make one HttpModule that is tightly coupled to the DI container and is part of the composition root. 内容: @supercat: agreed about the documentation. Sometimes you need to transfer ownership and you want to make that very clear in the docs or through the API. But even better than good documentation is good coding practices. Factories for instance are an obvious place where ownership is transformed; but constructors are not! The .NET framework has some places where it violates this and developers keep tripping over this, over and over again.

title: Lazy Dependency Injection
内容: The fact that DI containers have support for Lazy<T>, doesn't make it right to let your application code depend on a Lazy<T> dependency. Many DI containers support features that don't promote best practices. From a Dependency Injection perspective, Lazy<T> is a leaky abstraction. Please read this for an explanation on why Lazy<T> leaks.

title: VS 2013 Express, working with Unity configuraion, no IntelliSense support
内容: What about not using XML at all? XML based DI configuration is brittle, error prone and always provides a subset of what you can achieve with code based configuration. General consensus is to use code based configuration as much as possible and only fall back to file based configuration for the parts of the configuration that really need to be customizable after deployment. Even for those few lines that do need to be configurable, it’s a bad idea to require the fully qualified type name in a configuration file. A configuration switch (true/false or simple enum) is more than enough.

title: Do DI Containers need to instantiate the object themselves in order to use constructor injection?
内容: In case your classes accept their dependencies through constructor arguments, it's hard to imagine that the container does not invoke the constructor, because how would it otherwise get the dependencies in and get the class correctly initialized. It is technically possible, but just calling the constructor is just so much easier, safer and faster in terms of performance.

title: what's the relationship between dependency lookup &Ioc
内容: Nope. Dependency Injection is not an implementation of IoC. Inversion of Control is a defining characteristic of a framework and allows a framework to run user code. DI however can be used both with or without a framework. Dependency Injection is also often seen as a specific form of the Dependency Inversion Principle, but even this is incorrect, since it is easy to apply dependency injection while violating the Dependency Inversion Principle. But they are of course all related.

title: Autofac - Do I need to manually dispose IContainer in MVC global.asax?
内容: That's not exactly true. If the AppDomain dies, the runtime will run all finalizers of all objects that still need finalization. So this means that any unmanaged resources (file handles, db connections, references to native memory, GDI+ images) are cleaned. But the Garbage Collector will not call any Dispose method for you. So if you do anything more in a dispose method that's not in a finalizer (doing some final logging to a database for instance) that code will not run.

title: Register generic types with constructor in SimpleInjector how?
内容: @HamedF: Because you didn't tell us in your question that your EntityRepository<T> depended on DbContext instead of MyContext :-). In Simple Injector you register a type as key in a dictionary and Simple Injector will look types up by key. It doesn't walk the inheritance hierarchy for you; it just looks for the exact type. So you have to register DbContext. For instance: container.RegisterPerWebRequest<DbContext, MyContext>();

title: Dependency Injection. Preparing for ASP.NET vNext
内容: The DI libraries for .NET are really mature and Microsoft will not get that level of maturity within the coming years (just take a look at how long it takes for Entity Framework to get there and how Unity DI is lacking behind). There will be many important features missing from ASP.NET's built-in DI container such as being able to verify an diagnose the container's configuration, and working with generic types. If you're developing a serious business application using DI, please pick a decent DI library.

title: How to make AutoFac use same instance of nested dependency per top-level object? (SignalR dependency injection per hub)
内容: What you are looking for is the per-object-graph lifestyle, which is something not many containers support. AFAIK Autofac doesn't either. The usual way to handle this is by starting a new lifetime scope A @JimBolla said.

title: Caliburn.Micro and Simple Injector - InjectProperties is deprecated - How to BuildUp()?
内容: @MarkusHütter: After reading this documentation, it seems to me that you should not have to build up IResult instances. IResult implementations are normal services and if they require dependencies, you should wire their dependencies as usual using constructor injection. And even if you want to revert to property injection on those IResult services, you can still let Simple Injector resolve those services for you. I don't see any reason for building up those types.

title: Passing an object reference to a constructor, is this DI?
内容: The DIP states "High-level modules should not depend on low-level modules. Both should depend on abstractions", and I think from that we can conclude that your are not adhering to DIP when you depend on a concrete 'lower level' type. So I would say: abstractions are not needed for DI, but are needed for DIP. But you're right, there's no way for us to know whether B is concrete or not.

title: Passing an object reference to a constructor, is this DI?
内容: Not exactly right. Inversion of Control is just "a defining characteristic of a framework". It simply describes that you can hook your code into the pipeline of a framework. Dependency Inversion Principle (DIP) is all about talking to abstractions, and Dependency Injection is about injecting dependencies. If you inject a concrete type, you don't adhere to the DIP, but are still doing Dependency Injection. When interacting with a framework, you often interact with concrete types, in that case there is no Dependency Inversion.

title: Resolution of the dependency failed - Unity
内容: One warning about the [NamedDependency]. This couples your code to Unity which is typically a bad thing. And the need for a [NamedDependency] is an indication of a LSP violation and ambiguity in the design of your application. In your case it is clear that you simply need a nameless registration. In other cases, you might be missing an abstraction to make the distinction clear between two two types (instead of using [NamedDependency]).

title: Dynacache doesn't cache data
内容: Where is your data cached? Is it cached inside the MemoryCacheService instance? If this is true, this might be the problem, since according to your previous question you registered it as transient. Perhaps it needs to be a singleton, but do note that this is something that you have to find out from reading the Dynacache docs. Perhaps this type is not thread-safe and you need to have multiple instances.

What I prevent from doing is letting handlers directly or indirectly depend on other command handlers, because that complicates the system. In that case,  you should simply extract the common logic from the handler into a service and inject that service into all handlers that need it.

title: Dependency injection: single class (WCF service) having multiple dependencies (DB repositories) how to handle?
内容: @OleksandrPshenychnyy: You don't apply the command/handler pattern to comply with DI: you these patterns to increase maintainability of your system. Your web services should expose commands and queries when your team owns the clients. When third-parties talk to your services, you need a RESTfull approach (instead of a use case approach). But when doing RESTfull, it still doesn't mean you can't use commands and queries internally.

title: Castle Windsor resolve array of generic interfaces

title: One DbContext per web request… why?
内容: @Masoud: You have to make sure the same DbContext instance is reused throughout the object graph you construct. If you build up the object graph manually, you do this be storing the instance in a local field and reuse it. If you use a DI framework, you have to configure the lifestyle of that registration. Usually you would use a scoped lifestyle, such as Per-Web-Request or something similar.

title: What is the difference between DependencyResolver.SetResolver and HttpConfiguration.DependencyResolver in WebAPI

This complicates your DI configuration tremendously and your solution does not make that easier. There's only one way to make that easier, have two containers, preferably in two separate applications.

title: How do I resolve type dependencies in regards of controller action?
内容: @user3564235: In your UnityControllerFactory.CreateController, don't fall back to calling the base behavior in case of an exception, because that will hide the real problem. Save yourself a lot of headackes and let the exception simply bubble up. Also prevent letting your repositories take a dependency on the container, that leads to the Service Locator anti-pattern. Also -if possible-, prevent having a base class (BaseController) that implements shared behavior or cross-cutting concerns. Having a base class just for the translations seems unneeded and only complicate matter.

内容: I updated the answer according to @blueling's feedback. btw, there was a bug in the GetServices method. The code checked for GetRegistration(serviceType, false) != null, but this predicate will usually yield false, since a registration for a collection is a different registration. Doing GetRegistration(typeof(IEnumerable<>).MakeGenericType(servic‌​eType), false) != null however will not work, since this will never return null (since Simple Injector makes this registration for you if its missing). So blueling's answer is much better.

title: Unity autowiring: to use or not to use?

They need manual registration, because the order in which decorators are applied is often crucial for the correctness of your system.

title: How do I resolve type dependencies in regards of controller action?
内容: @d_z: Letting the container inject runtime data makes it very hard (or even impossible) to have a DI configuration that is verifiable. Not being able to verify the configuration in a simple integration test or during app startup, will make the configuration very fragile, and means you will have to click through the entire application to check whether your configuration is correct.

title: Using dependency injection with ORM codr
内容: Take a look at concept of Domain-Driven Design. In DDD your entities are the core layer of your application and they are oblivious to the used ORM technology. Persistence of your entities is hidden behind Repository abstractions and the repository implementations might use an ORM and translate your entities to ORM specific classes so they can be persisted. If you practice DDD, you will certainly not let your ORM dictate the shape of your entities: you are in control.

title: ICommandHandler/IQueryHandler with async/await
内容: @Int3ὰ: From a consuming perspective, this will work fine, but there will certainly be problems with that approach. You still can't apply a generic decorator around these handlers, because the decorator must know whether the return type is async or not. Just imagine a simple logging decorator that wraps the decoratee in a try-finally and logs the duration of the operation. When applied to a async handler, the duration of the operation will always become close to zero, since the decorator will only work correctly when it applies a ContinueWith delegate to the returned Task.

title: DI with UnitOfWork and Repository patterns
内容: The reason this works out of the box is because the RegisterPerWebRequest extension methods make use of the WebRequestLifestyle. The WebRequestLifestyle inherits from the ScopedLifestyle base class which allows deterministic disposal of cached instances. In other words all scoped lifestyles (such as LifetimeScopeLifestyle, WebApiRequestLifestyle and WebRequestLifestyle) will ensure that created instances for that lifestyle will get disposed when the scope ends.

And the factory abstraction should definately not be in the Composition Root, but your implementation should. You will often have more implementations in your composition root for abstractions defined in your base layer. Take for instance an IUserContext with an MvcUserContext and WcfUserContext implementations.

title: Why is NullReferenceException being returned when trying to add an object to my cache?
内容: It's unfortunate that the .NET framework throws a NullReferenceException in this case, but the Cache class is not intended to be instantiated by the user. The reason it throws is because the internal CacheInternal hasn't been initialized, but the way to do this is by calling SetCacheInternal which is an internal method. This method is called by ASP.NET when creating a cache instance for the current request.

title: Using SimpleInjector Is there a way to replicate RegisterWebApiRequest<T>() with .net 4/webapi 1?
内容: Do note that we deliberately chose to NOT support .NET 4.0 for Web API, because the WebApiRequestLifestyle makes use of CallContext.LogicalGetData which behaves different under .NET 4.0. This behavior is so significantly different that it can cause bugs when using nested ExecutionContextScope instances in background threads. To prevent developers from falling into this trap we decided to only support .NET 4.5.

title: Simple injector: Get root of the graph
内容: @RobertHarvey: The reason this is rather complicated to do in this case is because the RegisterWithContext extension methods use a callback delegate that allows changing the expression tree of the parent before it gets compiled, but you can't go to the parent's parent with this technique, since the parent can be a singleton (an Expression.Constant). In other words, at the time the parent's parent gets intercepted, its child is already an Expression.Constant (its expression tree is already compiled and executed) and can't be changed. You can do this as long as the whole graph is transient

title: ASP.NET MVC creates controllers which require authentication although the user is unauthenticated which leads to a dependency injection issue

It's the System.Web.Mvc.Controller class that handles the authorization and it can only do authorization when it's called. MVC can't do the authorization itself, since it allows you to completely replace the authorization mechanism.

内容: @julealgon: And about state: if you register all components as transient, there will effectively be no state in the container, since each Resolve would build a complete new set of objects. You can get this same statelessness with a single container. And having a single container with per-web-request registrations gives the same sort of state and behavior as a container-per-web-request gives you, only with much higher performance. And btw, I have never seen complete stateless web applications. There is always some cache, some singletons (and don't forget: some database).

title: Dependencies registration in Application_BeginRequest() method
内容: @julealgon: What you're basically saying is "if the container wouldn't do any optimizations at all, would you still advice against this". The answer is yes. Without any optimizations the framework will be quite slow, and there will still be a lot of overhead in registering instances on each request. And if the container is that slow, it becomes even more importantly to optimize by using per-app-domain scoped instances, but this is much harder to register when you have a container per request and this hinders maintainability.

title: DDD Stateless Services and Constructor Injection
内容: I believe that Evens meant something different than you think. I think he compares the state of a service with the state of a domain object. A domain object will clearly have state and change its state during its lifetime. A service won't -or shouldn't- change state and I think that that is what he means by 'stateless'. I think it is impossible to make a service completely stateless, since it will always run in some sort of statefull context; an UnitOfWork for instance, or a DB transaction. The service will always be effected by this, whether you inject dependencies or use service location.

title: where do I put AutoFac in multiple project solution
内容: Autofac is configured in the Composition Root. The Composition Root is a layer on its own, but in the case of a web application its quite normal to place this layer together with the UI layer in the same assembly. This doesn't mean however that this becomes one layer. It's quite normal to have multiple layers (which are logical artifacts) in a single assembly (which is an deployment artifact). There's nothing wrong with having multiple layers in a single assembly.

title: What does kernel.Bind<SomeType>().ToSelf() do?
内容: The type you use in Bind<T> is used as key. That's the type that will be resolved. Ninject 'knows' about that bind-type, not about the to-implementation. It just uses that to-implementation to construct the type. But sometimes you want to register some concrete type and have consumers that depend on that concrete type; not on one of its interfaces. For that you use Bind<MyType>().ToMyType>() or its shortcut: Bind<MyType>().ToSelf().

title: The appropriateness of dependency injection
内容: Your application code should NEVER depend on the container, and there's always a way to prevent this. Only intrastructure classes that are placed INSIDE the composition root should depend (if needed) on the container. If you have a situation where you think you need to depend on the container, ask a question about this here at SO.

title: Simple Injector in its own project
内容: The difference is that: your presentation layer (PL) depends on your DAL -only- when (some of) the classes of the PL (your controllers, views, etc) depend on classes in the DAL. It doesn't matter whether the PL's assembly takes a dependency on the DAL assembly, as long as the PL's types don't depend on DAL types.

title: How do I inject dependencies into a custom RoleProvider with Windsor?
内容: Well, if you make the 'real' provider a proxy to the provider that is resolved, you allow that provider to be built-up by the container and allow all that code to be tested. By resolving the provider on each call you also prevent any dependencies from living too long, since the 'real' provider is a singleton. If this is all not any concern and the provider only has one static dependency, there's indeed little reason not to go with the Service Locator-constructor approach.

title: Can a second parameter be passed to Controller constructors?
内容: Your constructors should do as little as possible and just accept the dependencies it needs. Your constructor should not use some integer to get the right repository, it should just require that repository to be passed into the constructor. And don't pass in runtime values through the constructor. That's what's the action method is for. Use the runtime value from the action method and pass it on to the proper service.

title: Delegate vs interface with a single method for DI

Take for instance an Func<DateTime>. What does it return? It could return a not of things, like the current time, the current day, or... we don't know. An ITimeProvider interface on the other hand describes clearly what to expect from that dependency

title: Should I use Destructor when I inherit from IDisposable?

内容: That article indeed is mine. The Repository pattern that Martin Fowler describes contains a Matching(Criteria) method, where such criteria can be combined of other criteria to build up a query. This criteria is an example of the Specification Pattern. You can see this 'query/handler pattern' (as I call it) as a Query Object, but without the criteria. It's part of a larger concept of Message Based Programming / Architecture. I still use the repository pattern in my applications (although in my last application, the repository is just a facade on top of generic GetByIdQuery<T> queries).

When you start exposing IQueryable<T> from your repository you will violate the LSP, and when you start adding extra query methods to specific repository implementations (as Eric Evens proposes in DDD) you will violate SRP, OCP, and ISP. Note that this probably makes sense when doing DDD, but you have to weigh the pres and cons clearly.

title: How to use Simple injector, Repository and Context - code first
内容: When resolving a type, Simple Injector will inject the dependencies into the constructor of that type. If your HomeController depends on BBLProducts, and you resolve a HomeController, Simple Injector will create a BBLProducts for you. If BBLProducts depends on IRepository<Product>, Simple Injector will inject an EFRepository<Product> into that BBLProducts for you. Simple Injector will build up a complete graph of related objects for you. You only have to resolve the root object, and in the case of MVC, this root object (a controller) is resolved for you.

If you forget to register one of those dependencies, the controller would still be able to be created, but the property will be null. This will cause a NullReferenceException later on. It's best to have the application fail a.s.a.p. which means you should use constructor injection.

title: What are the internal differences of a T[] and a List<T> in terms of memory?
内容: Technically, a List<T> IS a wrapper for an array. It holds a reference to an array internally, so an List<T> consumes more memory (assuming that the internal array is completely filled). But this difference is very small (List<T> consumer somewhere around 20 to 30 bytes of extra memory), so don't optimize prematurely.

title: Getting a lock using an object, rather than this - Threading
内容: The advice to not to use lock(this) must be placed in perspective. The Framework Design Guidelines advice against this, because it is bad from a framework perspective. A consumer of your framework can always take a lock on an instance of a type in your framework, which could accidentally lead to a deadlock. When writing a LOB application, there is full control over which code is written and this might not be such a big problem. I would say that in that case lock(this) is fine, but using a lock on an instance of another type is actually bad practice.

title: How to denote component lifetime when using convention-based registration?

An example of CoC is this: container.RegisterManyForOpenGeneric(typeof(IValidator<>), assembly). Here all validators are registered in one line, using the convention that they implement a certain interface. And this example directly shows the problem, since now all types are registered as transient. But what if one of those validators must be registered as singleton? That's what the question is about.

title: AOP implemented with the Decorator pattern over a Generic Repository
内容: @Aaron: Decorators should not know anything about the thing they decorate, except of course that it is an implementation of that interface. This allows you to stack decorators in any way you like and change it later on without breaking anything. So the security decorator just calls the decoratee and in your configuration this happens to be the logging decorator, but the security decorator neither knows or cares. The same holds for the logging decorator.

This will mean your composition root will become a maintenance nightmare. 3. Performance will drop considerably.

title: Emulate new request in Unit Tests
内容: That seems like a uninteresting thing to unit test to me. You should have an integration test that tests whether the DbContext is registered correctly, and in your unit tests you simply create the object graph manually. During unit tests the graph will we very shallow, since you'll mock everything but the class under test. So there's no need to reuse the same instance within the test, and there's no need to let the IoC container resolve an object graph. You shouldn't even use a IoC container in your tests.

title: Can we make Entity Framework create simpler sql?
内容: @marc_s: I've got a lot experience with query tuning and done a lot of tuning of LINQ queries and LINQ generated SQL queries. You are right that you'll of course need the proper indexes and statistics, but sometimes the SQL that EF (or L2S) generates can be very inefficient for SQL server. And when queries get very big and complex, SQL server's query plan will be suboptimal and performance can drop considerably. That doesn't mean though that it is anyone's 'fault'. There are just limitations to the tools we use (EF, SQL, etc) that we have to deal with.

title: Too much dependency injection for web app and web service layer?
内容: IoC containers can easily handle many layers deep and in most cases without any noticeable performance hit. I've seen well structured applications with object graphs for up to 14 levels deep. This is fine, because it is managed by the IoC container, and prevents you from thinking about this.

title: Dependency injection (ninject) using strings, anti-pattern?

title: Performance concern when using LINQ “everywhere”?
内容: In the (IoC) framework I'm maintaining I prevent object allocations in the framework's happy path, since it's users might use the framework in performance critical applications. Since LINQ and collection enumeration in general causes allocation of heap objects, I prevent using LINQ. For everything outside of the happy path however (which is 95% of the code base), I make extensive use of LINQ because it makes programming easier, more maintainable, and more fun. But note that I only prevent LINQ in that 5% because I build a reusable framework where this kind of performance is critical.

title: Separating the service layer from the validation layer
内容: If any peace of logic can't do what it promises, it should throw an exception. A command handler should not silently fail, so you should absolutely throw an exception. A decorator must return the same data as the command would (it is the same contract) so returning validation results should be done using an exception. Take a look at the ValidationException of DataAnnotations; it takes the same approach.

Whenever methods get behond 6 or 7 statements you should start looking more closely at those methods to see whether they still contain one level of abstraction. This doesn't mean that all methods can be short. There are always some methods that get bigger, such as methods that do object initialization (initialize 20 properties of an object), or methods that contain a large switch case statement (yes, they're still needed sometimes). But these methods are the exception to the rule.

title: DI with Unity when multiple instances of the same type is needed
内容: A factory is especially useful for delaying the creation of instances, but in your example you're still creating those queues during object graph construction. We could even argue that you complicated the design of Example, since it now depend on an extra abstraction. I would remove the IQueueFactory dependency from Example and if the use of the factory is needed, register it using an InjectionFactory as follows: container.Register<Example>(new InjectionFactory(c => new Example(c.Resolve<IQueueFactory>().Create("Receive"), c.Resolve<IQueueFactory().Create("Send"))));.

title: Ninject bindings 101
内容: So, what did you expect? That Ninject magically hooks into the .NET runtime and intercepts the creation of objects and notices that you created a new object and injected stuff into this? IoC containers are not magical unicorns. They force you to write your code in a specific way: let the container/kernel build up a graph of objects and request the root object from the container/kernel.

title: AoP support in NServiceBus?

With NServiceBus, you probably want to decorate your message handlers.

title: Why is a byte[] of 0 Length being injected into my class?

Prevent coming in this situation, by either registering the type A using a delegate (i.e. Bind<IA>().ToMethod(c => new A(hash))) or using a constructor argument override: Bind<IA>().To<A>().WithConstructorArgument("hash", hash). And if you need to inject this hash into multiple components, it might be better to hide this hash behind an abstraction (such as IHashingProvider).

title: Decorators and IDisposable
内容: Did you read my answer? You give GZipStream as an example of a class that disposes the resource it gets from the outside, but this design goes against the basic framework design guidelines and is the opposite of how most implementations work .NET. Without a container you would use a series of using statements to dispose a nested graph, and very few implementation should actually dispose the chain, since this is behavior that users usually wont expect and disallows reuse of the out objects. The inner objects simply can't know if their parents should be reused or not.

title: What is the best way to inject repositories into an ASP.NET controller
内容: "Appropriate" means: if you can do it, you should do it! Injecting services that are not always used at runtime should not be a problem, since object graph construction should be really fast (which means: don't do anything in your constructors besides storing references). If you inject more than 5 dependencies, you are probably violating the Single Responsibility Principle. This will result in maintainance problems. If you need to delay the creation of a type, you can't use ctor and prop injection, but you shouldn't use service locator, since you can use a factory.
